prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120) and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183

title: Ecosystem Ecology
description: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI E106 or EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C
restriction: Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Ecology and Evolutionary Biol Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Selfish DNA
description: Focuses on the genetics and evolution of selfish DNA, and introduces necessary background knowledge from molecular biology, cytogenetics, and bioinformatics.
prerequisite_tree: {"OR":["BIO SCI 94","BIO SCI 97","BIO SCI H94","BIO SCI H97"]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI 94', 'BIO SCI 97', 'BIO SCI H94', 'BIO SCI H97']
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 94 or BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI H94 or BIO SCI H97

title: Marine Biology
description: Examines the biotic and abiotic factors influencing the physiology, distribution, abundances, interactions, and evolution of marine organisms and the roles of those organisms in mediating ecosystem services and functions. A field trip is required. Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 94 or BIO SCI H94

title: Physiology and Pathology of the Kidney
description: Examines the structure, function, and pathology of the kidney. Topics include anatomy of the kidney, cellular function, urine formation, and disease states of the kidney.

title: Infectious Disease Dynamics
description: Learn how the immune system interacts with infectious diseases, in particular with viral infections. An introduction to basic virology and immunology, it concentrates on the way in which the immune system is critical to the prevention of infections.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 96 OR BIO SCI 97 OR BIO SCI E106 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED

title: Physiological Plant Ecology
description: An examination of the interactions between plants and their environment. Emphasis on the underlying physiological mechanisms of plant function, adaptations and responses to stress, and the basis of the distribution of plants and plant assemblages across the landscape.
prerequisite_text: EARTHSS 51 or BIO SCI 94 or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C)
restriction: Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Environmental Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Earth System Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Chemical Ecology
description: An introduction to the unspoken chemical language of nature. Emphasis on interactions between insects, plants, and microbes including plant defense, pollination, and microbial warfare.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 94 and CHEM 51A. CHEM 51A with a grade of C- or better

title: Image Analysis in Biological Research
description: Introduction to scientific image analysis including techniques such as high-speed, time-lapse, thermal imaging, and flow visualization. Students make movies using cameras, edit and analyze images using computers, and do a writing project.
prerequisite_tree: {"AND":[{"OR":["BIO SCI 100","BIO SCI 108"]},{"OR":["PHRMSCI 120","BIO SCI E106","BIO SCI E109"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI E106', 'PHRMSCI 120', 'BIO SCI E109', 'BIO SCI 100', 'BIO SCI 108']
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI E106 or PHRMSCI 120 or BIO SCI E109) and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
restriction: Seniors only.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2020 Winter', '2020 Summer2', '2021 Winter', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2021 Summer2', '2021 Fall', '2022 Summer1', '2022 Summer10wk', '2022 Summer2', '2022 Fall']

title: Environmental Microbiology
description: Focuses on non-pathogenic microbes within all habitats (soils, oceans, associated with animals and plants) and their essential functions for ecosystems. Their applied importance for agriculture, bioremediation, energy and food production are also discussed.

title: Microbiomes
description: Students develop an understanding of microbiomes in the context of both their environment and their impact on host physiology. Discussions on how microbiomes interact with the human body.

title: The Physiology of Human Nutrition
description: Examines the biochemical basis of energy metabolism, physiological processes in digestion and uptake, and the biochemical transformation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins in the human body. The emphasis is on expanding the students' understanding of physiology.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 98 and (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120)
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2020 Winter', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2021 Winter', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2022 Winter', '2022 Summer2']

title: Comparative Animal Physiology
description: Maintenance aspects of physiology: water balance; feeding and digestion; metabolism; respiration and circulation.

title: Animal Locomotion
description: The physiology, biomechanics, and neuroscience that determines how animals propel themselves and navigate through the world. Considers the principles that govern the walking, running, flying, and swimming of animals, including exercising humans.

title: Evolution and the Environment Laboratory
description: Explores basic topics in ecology and evolutionary biology and applications to agriculture, conservation, environmental issues, and public health. Format involves lab activities and discussion of scientific journal articles, with focus on learning to evaluate scientific evidence.
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E106
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
description: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.
prerequisite_text: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
restriction: Juniors only.

title: Animal Coloration and Vision
description: Physiological and behavioral mechanisms of color production and vision including crypsis, mimicry, aposematism, masquerade, sexual dimorphism, and predator-prey interactions through the lens of signals, receivers, and receptors; color and polarization vision in mate choice and visual adaptations to aquatic environments.

title: Ecosystem Services
description: Covers what ecosystem services are, how to classify them, what the impacts of land degradation are on ecosystem services, how to quantify and value them, and the importance of mainstreaming ecosystem services in decision-making.
prerequisite_text: (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)

title: Behavioral Endocrinology
description: Comparative examination of the major hormone systems that regulate behavior across animals. Emphasizes the reciprocating nature of hormone-behavior interactions and seeks to understand how natural selection drives the evolution of hormone structure and function.

title: Conservation Biology
description: Genetic and ecological issues in conservation biology, including effects of human population growth, the value of biodiversity, conservation genetics, demography, metapopulation dynamics, community and ecosystem processes, species invasions, global climate change, and reserve design and management.

title: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
description: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism; the spread and control of infectious diseases; and the in vivo dynamics of viral infections and the immune system.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93

title: Functional and Structural Evolutionary Genomics
description: Function and organization of genomes analyzed from an evolutionary perspective. Review of some of the most recent experimental approaches in genome analysis and comparative genomics. Relevant software to analyze DNA and expression data is used.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI H97

title: Genetics and Human History
description: Explores topics in human health/history from an evolutionary perspective, with emphasis on genetics. Topics include the relationship between genetics and human disease as an evolutionary question, and how modern genetic techniques are used to study the history of human populations.

title: Physiology in Extreme Environments
description: An in-depth look at the physiological mechanisms that allow animals, including humans, to be physically active and survive in extreme environments. Physiological responses to high altitude, diving, microgravity, deserts, and extreme cold are examined.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 94 or BIO SCI H94

title: Biology of Birds
description: A thorough introduction to the biology of birds, covering topics ranging from avian anatomy and physiology to behavior, natural history, ecology, genetics, evolution, systematics, and conservation. Examples from both local and global avifauna.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 94 AND BIO SCI E160L AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED

title: Biology of Birds Lab
description: The companion to Biology of Birds (E160). Consists primarily of field trips to identify local birds and study avian natural history. Students must provide their own transportation to field sites, some with entrance fees. Students must have field binoculars.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 194S AND ( BIO SCI 100 OR BIO SCI 108 ) AND SENIOR STANDING ONLY AND LOWER DIVISION WRITING AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Field Biology
description: Conducting group and independent studies in Southern California ecosystems, this course covers the fundamentals of experimental design, statistical analysis, communicating scientific findings (orally, visually, in writing), and other skills necessary for the scientific investigation of biological processes in the field.  Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
restriction: Seniors only.

title: Evolution
description: An integrative treatment of evolutionary biology that covers evolutionary processes, basic research methods, and the history of life.

title: Plant Diversity in a Changing World
description: Investigation of planet diversity in California and throughout the world, including basic systematic concepts, an introduction to major groups of flowering plants, and the effects of global biological change on plant diversity.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 96 OR BIO SCI E106 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED

title: Limnology and Freshwater Biology
description: Biology of freshwater environments: lakes, ponds, rivers, their biota, and the factors which influence distribution of organisms.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 94 OR BIO SCI H94 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2020 Winter', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2021 Winter', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2022 Winter']

title: Field Freshwater Ecology
description: Analytical techniques for common water-quality variables of lakes, streams, and rivers. Benthic fauna, vertebrates and invertebrates, algae, and aquatic plants. Emphasis on field methods with an experimental approach; laboratory exercises. Field trips to marshes, vernal pools, rivers, and streams. Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI E179
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Spring', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2019 Summer2', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2020 Summer2', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2022 Winter']

title: Mediterranean Ecosystems: Biodiversity and Conservation
description: Biodiversity, history of human impacts, and conservation efforts are examined in the five Mediterranean-type ecosystems. Remaining natural habitat, approaches to ecological habitat restoration, control of exotic species, and predicted consequences of global climate change are described. Field trip required.

title: Exercise Physiology
description: Focus upon critical topics in the area of exercise biology using the comparative physiological approach. Specifically examine the physiological factors that limit the capacity of an organism to sustain high levels of aerobic metabolism.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 98 and (BIO SCI E109 or PHRMSCI 120)
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI E117A', 'BIO SCI E117B', 'BIO SCI E117C']

title: Ecology and Diversity of Insects
description: Insects—representing two-thirds of all species—play fundamental roles in human health, agriculture, and natural ecosystems. Topics include insect morphology, development, physiology, taxonomy, ecology, and insects in human affairs. Lecture includes interactive demonstrations and an optional weekend trip.  Materials fee.

title: Population and Community Ecology
description: Population structure, function, development, and evolution. Topics include population structure, population growth and regulation, metapopulations, predation, competition, species diversity, ecosystem function, macroecology, and island biogeography. Offered every other Winter.

title: Population and Community Ecology Lab
description: Covers processes specific to groups of the same species (populations) and multiple species (communities). Includes growth, regulation, dynamics, and persistence of populations and community interactions, development, diversity, and macroecology. Lab activities focus on application of population prediction and biodiversity assessment.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI E106 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
restriction: Seniors only.

title: Exercise as Medicine
description: Explores the link between regular physical activity and health, focusing on mechanistic insights into how regular exercise improves overall health and alters disease trajectories of cancer, type-II diabetes, depression, and other chronic  illnesses.

title: Introduction to Insect Physiology
description: Physiology of insects. Insect respiration, digestion, excretion, and neurobiology, including sensory systems and effectors.

title: Environmental Ethics
description: History of evolution of environmental ethics in America. Management problems in national parks, wilderness areas, wild and scenic rivers, national forests. Contemporary and historical aspects/contributors to the field. Mitigation, endangered species, habitat restoration, biodiversity, and environmental activism. Field trips required.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

title: Topics in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
description: Studies in selected areas of ecology and evolutionary biology.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 106 OR BIO SCI E106 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

title: Honors Topics in Biological Sciences
description: Varied course topics in Biological Sciences designed for students in Honors in Biological Sciences.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Biological Sciences Honors students only.

title: The Idiom and Practice of Science
description: The importance of biological sciences in our world is discussed. Topics may include brain and behavior, health and disease, genetics and society, and conservation biology. Primary goal is to encourage students to understand better the world in which they live.
restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only.

title: Honors From DNA to Organisms
description: Cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, and the biology or organ systems. Covers concepts of building blocks (nucleotides, amino acids, and cells) and of information flow (DNA to proteins, receptors to nuclei, the blood to distant organs, and DNA to offspring).
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI 94', 'BIO SCI H94', 'BIO SCI E109', 'BIO SCI M115', 'BIO SCI N122', 'BIO SCI N123L', 'BIO SCI N129', 'BIO SCI N147', 'BIO SCI E151', 'BIO SCI N152', 'PSYCH 161H', 'PUBHLTH 182']
restriction: BIO SCI H93 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI 98.

title: Honors From Organisms to Ecosystems
description: Patterns of diversity, ecology, and evolutionary biology. Emphasis is on the Tree of Life and how its members are distributed and interact.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI E106', 'BIO SCI E119', 'BIO SCI E120', 'BIO SCI E155', 'BIO SCI E179']
restriction: BIO SCI 1A may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI H94.

title: Honors Genetics
description: Introduction to genetics. Basic features of replication and expression of DNA, cell division, and gene transmission. Recombination and mutation in diploid organisms.
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI 98', 'BIO SCI D105', 'BIO SCI E119', 'BIO SCI D137', 'BIO SCI E153']
restriction: Campuswide Honors Collegium students only. BIO SCI H97 may not be taken for credit if taken after BIO SCI 97.

title: Advanced Biochemistry
description: Physical-chemical properties of macromolecules. Structure-function relationships in nucleic acids, protein, carbohydrates, and lipids. Integration and regulation of metabolism. Biochemistry of organs and biochemistry of diseases.

title: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Properties of enzymes and the culture and isolation of mutants of microorganisms. Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Spring', '2020 Winter', '2020 Spring', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Spring', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Spring', '2022 Fall']

title: Allied Health Microbiology
description: Introductory microbiology lecture and laboratory with an emphasis on microbial growth control and the relationship between microbes and human health.
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93) and CHEM 1C. CHEM 1C with a grade of C- or better
restriction: Program in Nursing Science students have first consideration for enrollment.
overlap: BIO SCI M122, BIO SCI M118L.

title: Advanced Molecular Biology
description: Mechanisms of gene expression; special emphasis on regulatory events that occur in Eukaryotic organisms other than initiation of transcription. Chromatin structure and rearrangement, RNA polymerases, cis- and trans-acting elements, RNA processing, transport and stability, protein synthesis, trafficking, and turnover.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI M114L or BIO SCI M116L)

title: Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Students perform experiments which illustrate the chemical and biological properties of nucleic acids. Emphasis is placed on recent techniques in recombinant DNA technology including gene isolation and characterization.  Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI M116', 'BIO SCI M121L', 'BIO SCI M130L']
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Spring', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2019 Fall', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer2', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2021 Summer2', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer1', '2022 Summer10wk', '2022 Fall']

title: Experimental Microbiology Laboratory
description: Introductory general microbiology designed for preprofessional biology majors. Includes microscopy, cultivation of bacteria, morphological and biochemical characterization of bacteria, microbial metabolism, growth and genetics, microorganisms and human disease, and interactions of microorganisms with the environment.  Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108)
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Spring', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2019 Summer2', '2019 Fall', '2020 Winter', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2020 Summer2', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2021 Summer2', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer1', '2022 Summer10wk', '2022 Summer2', '2022 Fall']

title: Advanced Topics in Immunology
description: Literature-based, interactive discussions focused on review of seminal historic and recent immunology literature. Student responsibilities include reading, critical evaluation, and discussion of manuscripts.
restriction: Microbiology and Immunology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Signal Transduction in Mammalian Cells
description: Introduction to major biochemical pathways that transmit information from extracellular cues into changes in cell behavior. Focuses on kinases, phosphateses, G proteins, second messengers, and protein-protein interactions. Includes discussion of primary research articles and experimental techniques.

title: Immunology with Hematology
description: Antibodies, antigens, antigen-antibody reactions, cells and tissues of lymphoreticular and hematopoietic systems, and individual and collective components of cell-mediated and humoral immune response.
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI M119', 'BIO SCI M121L', 'BIO SCI M124B', 'BIO SCI N127', 'BIO SCI M131']
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Fall', '2020 Winter', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Fall']

title: Advanced Immunology Laboratory
description: Emphasis is placed on learning modern techniques in immunology such as ELISAs, western blotting, and immunofluorescent staining assays.   Materials fee.
prerequisite_tree: {"AND":["BIO SCI M121","BIO SCI M116L",{"OR":["BIO SCI 100","BIO SCI 108"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI 100', 'BIO SCI 108', 'BIO SCI M116L', 'BIO SCI M121']
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI M116L and BIO SCI M121
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: General Microbiology
description: Comparative metabolism of small molecules and cell structure and relationship to microbial classification. Macromolecule synthesis and regulation, sporulation, cell division, growth, and effect of antibiotics.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Spring', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2019 Summer2', '2020 Winter', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer2', '2020 Fall', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer2', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer2', '2022 Fall']

title: Introduction to Computational Biology
description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
prerequisite_text: ( MATH 7 OR MATH 2D OR MATH 2J OR STATS 7 OR STATS 8 OR BIO SCI 7 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED

title: Virology
description: Replication of viruses in populations, animals, and the host cell. The effects of viral infection on populations, individuals, and specific molecular effects on the target cell. Role of viral infections in cancer and degenerative diseases.
restriction: School of Biological Sciences students only.

title: Viral Pathogenesis and Immunity
description: The mechanisms of viral pathogenesis and of host resistance to viruses are explored in detail. HIV-1 and Influenza-A are used as examples. In each case, viral replication, cytopathic effects, immune response, and viral evasion are discussed.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M124A. Recommended: BIO SCI M122.

title: Molecular Biology of Cancer
description: Molecular mechanisms of carcinogenesis. Consideration of transformation by DNA tumor viruses, RNA tumor viruses, and chemical carcinogens.

title: Learning to Read Primary Literature in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: An introduction to primary literature focusing on methods to approach, understand, and analyze scientific papers.

title: Advanced Molecular Lab Techniques
description: Discovery-driven experimentation in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and cell biology. Also involves other aspects of the lab experience including group discussion of results, scientific paper analysis, and student presentations.   Materials fee.
prerequisite_tree: {"AND":["BIO SCI 100","BIO SCI 194S",{"OR":["BIO SCI D111L","BIO SCI M114L","BIO SCI M116L","BIO SCI M118L"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI 100', 'BIO SCI M114L', 'BIO SCI D111L', 'BIO SCI M118L', 'BIO SCI M116L', 'BIO SCI 194S']
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 100 AND BIO SCI 194S AND ( BIO SCI D111L OR BIO SCI M114L OR BIO SCI M116L OR BIO SCI M118L ) AND LOWER DIVISION WRITING AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Innate Immunity, Infection, and Pathogenesis
description: Role of the innate immune system in health and disease. Molecular pathways of innate immune recognition, expression, and regulation of immune receptors, signal transduction, pathogen sensors, and detection of microbial ligands. Lecture and discussion of primary research articles.
prerequisite_tree: {"OR":["BIO SCI M121","BIO SCI M122","BIO SCI M143","BIO SCI M124A","BIO SCI M124B"]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI M121', 'BIO SCI M122', 'BIO SCI M124A', 'BIO SCI M124B', 'BIO SCI M143']
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M122 or BIO SCI M124A or BIO SCI M124B or BIO SCI M143

title: Structural Biology
description: Basic principles of magnetic resonance, X-ray crystallography, and CryoEM toward the determination of high-resolution biomolecular structures.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

title: Microbial Genetics
description: Basic principles of microbial genetics are presented as lectures for the first half of the course. The second half is devoted to applications of these principles and requires reading review and original research papers and interactions with guest lecturers.

title: Human Parasitology
description: Introduction to human animal-parasitic diseases including worms and protozoan infections.

title: Cell Organelles and Membranes
description: Structure, function, and biogenesis of biological membranes and membrane-bound organelles.

title: Vascular Biology: Blood Vessels in Health and Disease
description: Every cell in the body is within a half hair’s width of a blood vessel. As such, we cannot understand the body, in health or disease, without understanding the vasculature. Mixes lectures and primary literature reviews.

title: Structure-Function Relationships of Integral Membrane Proteins
description: Integral membrane proteins such as voltage and ligand-gated ion channels, water channels, pumps, cotransporters, and receptors (e.g., GPCRs). The emphasis is on the relationship between atomic structure and the functional properties of these proteins.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99. BIO SCI 98 with a grade of B or better. BIO SCI 99 with a grade of B or better

title: Biotechnological Applications of  Energy and Environmental Research
description: Covers microbiological and biochemical background related to current biotechnological applications, case studies of biotech-companies, and basic information related to patents and start-up companies. Topics include biofuel, bioremediation, agricultural, and environmental applications.

title: Topics in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
description: Studies in selected areas of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

title: Neurobiology and Behavior
description: Consideration of the evolution of behavior, including ethological and psychological aspects and analysis of neuroanatomical, neurochemical, neurophysiological, and neuroendocrine systems underlying basic behavioral processes.
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI N113L', 'BIO SCI N118', 'BIO SCI N119', 'BIO SCI N150', 'BIO SCI N151', 'BIO SCI N153', 'BIO SCI N155', 'BIO SCI N158', 'BIO SCI N160', 'BIO SCI N165', 'BIO SCI N172', 'BIO SCI N173', 'BIO SCI N174', 'BIO SCI N176', 'BIO SCI N190', 'PSYCH 122P', 'PSYCH 160D', 'PSYCH 161', 'PSYCH 162N']
restriction: Students who require this class for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Spring', '2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer1', '2021 Summer10wk', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer2']

title: Neurobiology Laboratory
description: An in-depth exploration into biology and physiology of the nervous system. Labs include neuroanatomy, electrophysiology, pharmacology, behavior, experimental design, EEG, and scientific writing.  Materials fee.
prerequisite_tree: {"AND":[{"OR":["BIO SCI 100","BIO SCI 108"]},{"OR":["BIO SCI N110","BIO SCI N115A"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI 100', 'BIO SCI 108', 'BIO SCI N110', 'BIO SCI N115A']
prerequisite_text: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and (BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A)
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Spring', '2020 Winter', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer2', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Spring', '2022 Winter', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer2']

title: Advanced Neurobiology I
description: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging. Discussion of molecular, cellular, and developmental neurobiology.
prerequisite_for: ['BIO SCI N113L', 'BIO SCI N115B', 'BIO SCI N118', 'BIO SCI N119', 'BIO SCI N150', 'BIO SCI N151', 'BIO SCI N153', 'BIO SCI N155', 'BIO SCI N158', 'BIO SCI N165', 'BIO SCI N172', 'BIO SCI N173', 'BIO SCI N174', 'BIO SCI N176', 'BIO SCI N190', 'PSYCH 122P', 'PSYCH 160D', 'PSYCH 161', 'PSYCH 162N']
restriction: Neurobiology Majors only.

title: Advanced Neurobiology II
description: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging.
restriction: Neurobiology Majors only.

title: Introduction to Neuroscience Clinical Trials
description: Provides an overview of the science of clinical development of treatments for neurological disease and injury.

title: Clinical Psychophysiology
description: Psychophysiology investigates the relationships between physiological processes and psychological phenomena. Technologies examined include reaction times, heart rate variability, EEGs, ERPs, magnetoencephalography, and eye tracking. Applications include diagnosis, the longitudinal assessment, and the identification of individuals at risk of disease onset.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A

title: History of Neuroscience
description: An overview of the conceptual and technical foundations of contemporary neuroscience from ancient times to the present. The subjects include synapses, neurons, brain organization, sensory, motor and regulatory systems, learning and memory, human brain function and dysfunction.
prerequisite_tree: {"OR":["BIO SCI 35","BIO SCI N110","PSY BEH 115D","BIO SCI N115A",{"AND":["PSYCH 9A","PSYCH 9B","PSYCH 9C"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI 35', 'BIO SCI N110', 'BIO SCI N115A', 'PSY BEH 115D', 'PSYCH 9A', 'PSYCH 9B', 'PSYCH 9C']
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or PSY BEH 115D or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C)
restriction: Upper-division students only.

title: Human Biology I
description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.
restriction: Human Biology Majors only.

title: Human Biology II
description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.
restriction: Human Biology Majors only.

title: Human Biology III
description: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.
restriction: Human Biology Majors only.

title: Drug Addiction
description: Provides a comprehensive overview of topics in the addiction field, including drug pharmacology, models/approaches to investigate addiction, brain circuits, genetics, epigenetics, and the cellular and molecular biology of drug addiction.

title: Scientific Argumentation and Critical Thinking
description: Explicitly teaches argument structure, deductive logic, inductive logic, and common fallacies in the biology context. Students identify assumptions and fallacies in faulty arguments and data figures and learn to compose sound arguments.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 93 OR BIO SCI H93 ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED

title: Human Neuroimaging Lab
description: Hands-on laboratory course in human neuroimaging, with particular emphasis on using MRI to understand brain function and how it changes over the course of the lifespan and with disease.
prerequisite_text: ( BIO SCI 93 OR BIO SCI H93 ) AND ( BIO SCI 100 OR BIO SCI 108 ) AND LOWER DIVISION WRITING AND SCHOOL OF BIO SCI ONLY AND SENIOR STANDING ONLY AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: Seniors only. Students who require this lab for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Foundations in Neuroimmunology
description: The immune system supports normal brain development as well as controls central nervous system (CNS) infections and augments neurodegenerative and neurological diseases. Assesses how the immune system contributes to both host defense and disease.

title: The Transparent Brain
description: Teaches students how to perform new 3-D histology techniques that reveal the complex circuitry of the brain in unprecedented detail. Students work with real brain samples as part of ongoing neuroscience research projects. Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
restriction: Students who require this course for completion of their degree have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Human Neurodegenerative Diseases
description: Clinical and epidemiological aspects of neurodegenerative diseases causing dementia are reviewed, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, and Frontotemporal Dementia. Seminar format includes student presentation and group discussion.

title: Cognitive Neuroepigenetics
description: Current topics in the emerging field of cognitive neuroepigenetics focusing on understanding the underlying epigenetic mechanisms of memory formation and persistence. Primary literature is used to explore these processes.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Sex Differences in the Brain
description: Explores the neural bases of sex influences on brain function.

title: Hearing and the Brain
description: An overview of brain mechanisms of hearing, including perception of simple sounds, speech, and music. Begins with sound itself, and looks at processing by the ear, auditory pathways, auditory cortex, and beyond. Also auditory development, learning, and clinical issues.
prerequisite_text: PSYCH 160A or BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93
restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Brain Dysfunction and Repair
description: Introduction to the disruptions in brain function that underlie disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinsonism, schizophrenia, and depression, and the basis for drug therapies. The brain's ability to repair itself after damage and the pros and cons of that repair.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A
restriction: Neurobiology Majors only.

title: Neurobiology of Aging
description: Multidisciplinary overview of the functional capacity of the aging brain, its structural changes and the mechanisms underlying function and structure. Emphasis is on successful brain aging and those mechanisms which lead to the development of Alzheimer's disease.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Developmental Neurobiology
description: The development of the nervous system is discussed with emphasis on the processes that underlie the appearance of complex and highly ordered neural circuits. Topics include neural induction, specification, migration and death; axon growth, and neural circuit formation.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 93 or BIO SCI H93

title: Neuropharmacology
description: Survey of neurotransmitter systems, focusing on how transmitters are made, how they interact with their receptors, and how drugs can influence these processes to alter neural function and behavior.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Molecular Neurobiology
description: Provides a fundamental understanding of how the brain works at the molecular level. Topics include nature and actions of molecules that regulate the functioning of the brain and cellular mechanisms underlying learning and memory.

title: Wiring the Developing Brain
description: The development of the nervous system is discussed with particular emphasis on the processes that underlie the appearance of complex and highly ordered neural circuits. Basic neurodevelopmental processes are discussed and correlated with normal brain function/dysfunction.
prerequisite_tree: {"OR":["BIO SCI N110","BIO SCI N152","BIO SCI N115A"]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI N110', 'BIO SCI N115A', 'BIO SCI N152']
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A or BIO SCI N152

title: Molecular Mechanisms of Memory
description: Current topics focused on understanding the molecular mechanisms that contribute to synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory. Primary literature is used to explore the variety of molecular mechanisms underlying these processes.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory
description: How the brain and behavior change as a result of experience, with an emphasis on identifying the neurochemical processes through which memory is stored and the parts of the brain that are involved.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A
terms: ['2019 Summer1', '2019 Summer10wk', '2019 Fall', '2020 Summer1', '2020 Summer10wk', '2020 Fall', '2021 Fall', '2022 Fall']

title: Animal Behavior
description: Explores why animals behave the way they do from evolutionary/mechanistic perspectives. Considers selective pressures and evolutionary constraints that shape animal behavior and the underlying neural and hormonal mechanisms by using examples such as why dogs bark, why some birds migrate.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Language and the Brain
description: Research analysis on biological bases of human linguistic capacity. Development, focusing on hemispheric specialization, plasticity; localization of specific linguistic functions in adults, with emphasis on study of aphasias; relation of linguistic capacity to general cognitive capacity, considering research on retardation.
prerequisite_tree: {"AND":[{"OR":["PSCI 11B","PSYCH 9B","BIO SCI 35","PSY BEH 11B","BIO SCI N110"]},{"OR":["PSCI 9","PSCI 11A","PSYCH 7A","PSYCH 9A","PSY BEH 9","PSY BEH 11A"]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['PSCI 11A', 'PSYCH 7A', 'PSY BEH 11B', 'PSCI 9', 'PSY BEH 11A', 'PSY BEH 9', 'BIO SCI 35', 'BIO SCI N110', 'PSCI 11B', 'PSYCH 9B', 'PSYCH 9A']
prerequisite_text: ( PSCI 11B OR PSYCH 9B OR BIO SCI 35 OR PSY BEH 11B OR BIO SCI N110 ) AND ( PSCI 9 OR PSCI 11A OR PSYCH 7A OR PSYCH 9A OR PSY BEH 9 OR PSY BEH 11A ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Functional Neuroanatomy
description: How neuroscience uses tools of many disciplines, from imaging to behavior, to develop and test hypotheses about functions of specific parts of the brain. Basic organization of nerve cells/vertebrate nervous system; methods of visualizing nerve cells; neural connections/activity patterns.

title: Brain Disorders and Behavior
description: Examines the localization of human brain functions and the effects of neurological disorders on psychological functions such as perception, motor control, language, memory, and decision-making.
prerequisite_tree: {"OR":["PSCI 9","PSYCH 7A","PSY BEH 9","BIO SCI 35","BIO SCI N110",{"AND":[{"OR":["PSYCH 9A","PSY BEH 11A"]},{"OR":["PSYCH 9B","PSY BEH 11B","BIO SCI N115A"]}]}]}
prerequisite_list: ['BIO SCI N115A', 'PSY BEH 11B', 'PSCI 9', 'PSYCH 9A', 'PSY BEH 9', 'BIO SCI 35', 'PSY BEH 11A', 'BIO SCI N110', 'PSYCH 9B', 'PSYCH 7A']
prerequisite_text: ( PSCI 9 OR PSYCH 7A OR PSY BEH 9 OR BIO SCI 35 OR BIO SCI N110 OR ( ( PSYCH 9A OR PSY BEH 11A ) AND ( PSYCH 9B OR PSY BEH 11B OR BIO SCI N115A ) ) ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Spring', '2019 Summer2', '2020 Spring', '2020 Summer2', '2021 Spring', '2021 Summer2', '2022 Spring', '2022 Summer2']

title: Clinical Neuroscience
description: An introduction to the neuroclinical bases of human behavior, including neuropsychological approaches to mental disorders. Also includes case formulations, research articles, therapeutic approaches, and other discussions related to select psychopathology and other neurobehavioral topics.
prerequisite_text: ( PSCI 9 OR PSCI 11A OR PSYCH 7A OR PSYCH 9A OR PSY BEH 9 OR BIO SCI 99 OR PSY BEH 11A ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biological Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Social Ecology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Regenerative Neurobiology
description: Explores the field of regenerative neurobiology. Both basic stem cell discoveries and their potential clinical application to brain disorders examined. Opportunities, challenges, and implications of this research also discussed.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Human  Neuropsychology
description: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.
prerequisite_text: ( PSCI 11A OR PSYCH 9A OR PSY BEH 11A OR BIO SCI N110 OR BIO SCI N115A ) AND NO REPEATS ALLOWED
restriction: School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychological Science Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology and Social Behavior Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Principles of Neural Computation
description: Introduction to the theoretical principles and biological mechanisms underlying how brains acquire, assimilate, store, and retrieve information, and how they compute adaptive responses to external inputs.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Cerebral Cortex: Structure, Function, and Plasticity
description: The cerebral cortex is highly developed in mammals and is responsible for higher perceptual and cognitive functions. Explores some amazing aspects of cortical structure, function, and plasticity emphasizing primary literature.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A

title: Vision
description: Visual perception and the anatomy and physiology of the visual system. Topics include the retina and the visual pathway; visual sensitivity; color vision; spatial vision; motion perception; and the development of the visual system.
restriction: Upper-division students only. School of Biological Sciences students have first consideration for enrollment. Cognitive Sciences Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Psychology Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

title: Topics in Neurobiology and Behavior
description: Studies in selected areas of neurobiology and behavior.
prerequisite_text: BIO SCI N110 or BIO SCI N115A
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Introduction to the central topics of biomedical engineering. Offers a perspective on bioengineering as a discipline in a seminar format. Principles of problem solving, design, engineering inventiveness, entrepreneurship, information access, communication, ethics, teamwork, and social responsibility are emphasized.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.
terms: ['2019 Winter', '2019 Fall', '2020 Winter', '2020 Fall', '2021 Winter', '2021 Fall', '2022 Winter', '2022 Fall']

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomechanics I
description: Introduction to statics and dynamics. Topics include rigid bodies, analysis of structures, forces in beams, moments of inertia, friction, kinetics, work, and energy.
prerequisite_text: BME 60B AND BME 60C AND MATH 3A AND MATH 3D AND PHYSICS 7C
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomechanics II
description: Introduction to biomechanics from subcellular to tissue levels. Introduction to stress, strain, and constitutive laws of cells and tissues. Emphasis is placed on biosolids. Introduction to elastic and viscoelastic behaviors with emphasis on the standard linear model of viscoelasticity.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomechanics III
description: Introduction to human biomechanics with emphasis on cardiovascular biomechanics and biofluid mechanics.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Design of Biomaterials
description: Natural and synthetic polymeric materials. Metal and ceramics implant materials. Mechanical properties, degradation, surface characterization, and design of materials. Wound repair, blood clotting, foreign body response, biocompatibility of material. Artificial organs and medical devices. Government regulations.
prerequisite_text: CHEM 1C AND ( BME 50B OR BIO SCI 99 )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Genetic Engineering and Synthetic Biology
description: Exploring how biological function can be engineered and "synthesized" from the DNA level up.
prerequisite_text: BME 50A AND BME 50B AND MATH 3D AND ( CHEM 1C OR CHEM H2C )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Sensory Motor Systems
description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.
prerequisite_text: MATH 3D AND PHYSICS 7D AND ( BME 60B OR EECS 10 OR EECS 12 OR ENGRCEE 20 OR ENGRMAE 10 )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Materials Science and Engr Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Quantitative Physiology:  Organ Transport Systems
description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the cardiopulmonary, circulatory, and renal systems.
prerequisite_text: MATH 3D AND ( BME 60B OR EECS 10 OR EECS 12 OR ENGRCEE 20 OR ENGRMAE 10 )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Signals and Systems
description: Analysis of analog and digital biomedical signals; Fourier Series expansions; difference and differential equations; convolutions.  System models: discrete-time and continuous-time linear time-invariant systems; Laplace and Fourier transforms. Analysis of signals and systems using computer programs.
prerequisite_text: BME 60B AND MATH 3D AND STATS 8 AND ( MATH 3A OR I&C SCI 6N )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Introduction to Computational Biology
description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
prerequisite_text: MATH 2D or MATH 3A or STAT 7 or STAT 8

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Photomedicine
description: Studies the use of optical and engineering-based systems (laser-based) for diagnosis, treating diseases, manipulation of cells and cell function. Physical, optical, and electro-optical principles are explored regarding molecular, cellular, organ, and organism applications.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Engineering Medical Optics
description: Principles of optics and photonics, integration of optical components into systems and devices, and analysis of physiological signals obtained from Biophotonics measurements.
prerequisite_text: BME 130 AND ( BME 135 OR BIO SCI D130 )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
description: Introduction to imaging modalities widely used in medicine and biology, including X-ray, computed tomography (CT), nuclear medicine (PET and SPET), ultrasonic imaging, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), optical tomography, imaging contrast, imaging processing, and complementary nature of the imaging modalities.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Biological Systems
description: Principles of spectroscopy; absorption; molecular orbitals; multiphoton transitions; Jablonski diagram; fluorescence anisotropy; fluorescence decay; quenching; FRET; excited state reactions; solvent relaxations; instruments; microscopy: wide field, LSM, TPE; fluorescent probes, fluctuations spectroscopy; optical resolution and super-resolution; CARS and SHG microscopy.
prerequisite_text: MATH 3D AND STATS 8 AND ( MATH 3A OR I&C SCI 6N )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Design of Biomedical Electronics
description: Analog and digital circuits in bioinstrumentation. AC and DC circuit analysis, design and construction of filter and amplifiers using operational amplifier, digitization of signals and data acquisition, bioelectrical signals, design and construction of ECG instrument, bioelectrical signal measurement and analysis.  Materials fee.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Microfabrication
description: Essentials of photolithography, soft-lithography, microfabrication, Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS), BioMEMS; applications in biomedical engineering.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Microfluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip
description: Introduction to principles of microfluidics and state-of-the-art micro Total Analysis Systems (uTAS). Lab-on-a-Chip for bimolecular assays with device design principles for microscale sample preparation, flow transport, bimolecular manipulation, separation and detection, and the technologies for integrating these devices into microsystems.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Microimplants
description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biotransport Phenomena
description: Fundamentals of heat and mass transfer, similarities in the respective rate equations. Emphasis on practical application of fundamental principles.
prerequisite_text: MATH 3D AND ( BME 60B OR ENGRCEE 20 ) AND ( MATH 3A OR I&C SCI 6N )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Tissue Engineering
description: Quantitative analysis of cell and tissue functions. Emerging developments in stem cell technology, biodegradable scaffolds, growth factors, and others important in developing clinical products. Applications of bioengineering.
prerequisite_text: BME 111 AND BME 121 AND BME 150 AND ( BME 50B OR BIO SCI 99 )
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Chemical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Introduction to Modern Bioengineering Tools
description: A broad picture of diverse modern bioengineering tools, including genetic engineering and its risks to society, how to sequence DNA/RNA molecules with single base resolution, how to manipulate small biomolecules one at a time.
prerequisite_text: (BME 50A and BME 50B) or (BIOL 97 and BIOL 98 and BIOL 99)
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory
description: Measurement and analysis of biological systems using engineering tools and techniques. Laboratory experiments involve living systems with the emphasis on measuring physiological parameters. Materials fee.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Cell and Tissue Engineering Laboratory
description: Techniques in molecular, cellular, and tissue engineering.  Topics include bacterial and mammalian cell culture, DNA cloning and gene transfer, fabrication of biomaterial scaffolds, and immunassays and microscopy techniques for cell-based assays.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Engineering Design: Addressing Unmet Clinical Needs
description: Introduction to unmet clinical needs identification and evaluation in biomedical engineering design.
prerequisite_text: (BME 60B or MAE 10 or EECS 10) and (BME 60C or MAE 52 or EECS 31L) and (BME 140 or MAE 106 or EECS 170B)
restriction: Biomedical Engineering Majors have first consideration for enrollment. Biomedical Engr: Premedical Majors have first consideration for enrollment.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering; industrial design experience in group projects; ethics, economic analysis, and FDA product approval. Materials fee.
prerequisite_text: ( BME 60C OR EECS 31L OR ENGRMAE 52 ) AND ( BME 60B OR EECS 10 OR ENGRMAE 10 ) AND ( BME 140 OR EECS 170B OR ENGRMAE 106 )
restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering; industrial design experience in group projects; ethics, economic analysis, and FDA product approval. Materials fee.
restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Design strategies, techniques, tools, and protocols commonly encountered in biomedical engineering; industrial design experience in group projects; ethics, economic analysis, and FDA product approval. Materials fee.
restriction: Seniors only. Biomedical Engineering Majors only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Individual Study
description: Independent research conducted in the lab of a biomedical engineering core faculty member. A formal written report of the research conducted is required at the conclusion of the quarter.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 8 units.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Individual Study

repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Big Data
description: Analysis and visualization of large biomedical datasets. Topics covered include cloud computing, learning Structured Query Language (SQL), database normalization and joins, using Google’s BigQuery, using the statistical analysis package R, machine learning algorithms, application of machine learning for classification problems.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biomedical Imaging and Biophotonics
description: Designed as a subfield of optical imaging and biophotonics as it applies to their applications to basic lifesciences and in vivo imaging to diagnose disease. Topics span all of of the areas of biophotonics and techniques.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Digital Health
description: Digital health is the convergence of genomics and technology to radically change the way health and medicine is practiced. Explores the history of healthcare in the U.S., its current status, and the future of digital health.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Molecular and Cellular Engineering
description: Engineering of physiological function at the genetic, cellular, and tissue scales. Topics include cloning and genetic engineering, extracellular matrix biomaterials, principles of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering, and experimental design.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Molecular and Cellular Engineering
description: Engineering of physiological function at the genetic, cellular, and tissue scales. Topics include cloning and genetic engineering, extracellular matrix biomaterials, principles of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering, and experimental design.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Microscale Tissue Engineering
description: Engineering of physiological function at the scale of individual cells. Topics include cell micropatterning, microfluidic tissue culture, engineering the cellular microenvironment, and microphysiological systems.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Microscale Tissue Engineering
description: Engineering of physiological function at the scale of individual cells. Topics include cell micropatterning, microfluidic tissue culture, engineering the cellular microenvironment, and microphysiological systems.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Cardiovascular Mechanobiology
description: Advanced topics in cellular engineering and mechanobiology, with focus on the cardiovascular system.  Tools and techniques used to manipulate and measure mechanical forces at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ levels, and their applications in cardiovascular devices and tissue engineering.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Cardiovascular Mechanobiology
description: Advanced topics in cellular engineering and mechanobiology, with focus on the cardiovascular system. Tools and techniques used to manipulate and measure mechanical forces at the molecular, cellular, tissue, and organ levels, and their applications in cardiovascular devices and tissue engineering.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Systems Cell and Developmental Biology
description: Introduces concepts needed to understand cell and developmental biology at the systems level, i.e., how the parts (molecules) work together to create a complex output. Emphasis on using mathematical/computational modeling to expand/modify insights provided by intuition.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Linking Modeling and Experiments in Bioengineering
description: Overview of modeling based on experimental techniques in bioengineering. Construct and evaluate models of varying complexity and to relate them to experimental data.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Sensory Motor Systems
description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.
restriction: Graduate students only.

title: Sensory Motor Systems
description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the nervous and musculoskeletal systems.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Organ Transport Systems
description: A quantitative and systems approach to understanding physiological systems. Systems covered include the cardiopulmonary, circulatory, and renal systems.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Organ Transport Systems
description: Applies engineering models and mathematics to understand human physiology in order to understand the physiology. Covers the pulmonary, cardiac, and cardiovascular systems focusing on transport phenomena.
restriction: Master of Engineering students only. Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Biofluid Mechanics
description: Introduces principles of biofluid mechanics in a research oriented scheme and approaches a wide spectrum of biofluid related problems in human body and solutions that involves engineering concepts.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Molecular and Cellular Biophotonics
description: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to biomolecular and cellular systems. Sample technologies Optical Tweezers, Linear and Nonlinear Optical Microscopy and Fluorescence Lifetime and Correlation Methods, and their use to investigate emergent problems in Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Tissue and Organ Biophotonics
description: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to tissues, organs, organisms. Sample technologies include Optical Coherence Tomography, Optical Speckle Imaging, Optoacoustic Imaging, Wide-Field Spectroscopic Imaging, Diffuse Optical Spectroscopy. Addressing the use of these technologies to detect/monitor disease and physiological processes.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Applied Engineering Mathematics I
description: Analytical techniques applied to engineering problems in transport phenomena, process dynamics and control, and thermodynamics.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Applied Engineering Mathematics II
description: Focuses on biomedical system identification. Includes fundamental techniques of model building and testing such as formulation, solution of governing equations, sensitivity theory, identifiability theory, and uncertainty analysis.
restriction: Graduate students only.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Introduction to Computational Biology
description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering

description: Introduces principles of system theory to analyze biological, biochemical, physiological, and bioengineering systems. Analytical and computational tools are used to model and analyze dynamic systems such as population, neuronal and heart dynamics, biochemical and physiological systems, oxygen diffusion and similar.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering

description: Introduces the elements of system theory, and applies these principles to analyze biomedical, chemical, social, and engineering systems. Using analytical and computational tools to model and analyze various dynamic systems.

description: Knowledge and understanding of recent techniques for the analysis of healthy and pathological structure and function in neuroimaging data.

description: Hands-on introduction to techniques for the analysis of neural time series data, with a primary focus on the electroencephalogram (EEG). Topics may include the physiological basis of EEG, time-frequency analysis, spatial filtering, and methods of assessing connectivity.

title: Microimplants
description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.

title: Engineering Innovations in Treating Diabetes
description: Innovations in diabetes treatment from the 1800s until the present: purification of insulin, measuring and control of blood glucose, recombinant DNA, clinical trials, and ethics. Solving optimization problems in engineering with Excel.

title: Cell and Molecular Engineering
description: Molecular, structural, genetic, biophysical, and cellular principles of life and bioengineering. Introduction to molecular bioengineering, genetic engineering, synthetic biology, and cell biology. Applications to genetic and biomolecular design.

school: The Henry Samueli School of Engineering
title: Cell and Molecular Engineering
description: Physiological function from a cellular, molecular, and biophysical perspective. Introduction to genetics, neuronal signaling, and cell cycle control.
